translated: The Elders’ Birth Stories🔽. The Section with Similes

analyzed: vidhūpana dāyaka tthera apadāna  padumuttara buddhassa  loka jeṭṭhassa tādinaḥ
translated: The Elder Vidhūpanadāyaka🔽“I gave a handful of seed🔽to Padumuttara, the Buddha,
the Leader of the World, the Worthy One,
the One with Eyes, the Tathāgata.
Having gladdened my own mind,
having raised my joined palms,
I worshipped the Buddha,
and departed facing north.
Having taken the handful of seed,
the Teacher, the Leader of the World,
standing in the midst of the Saṅgha of monks,
recited these verses:
‘By this gift of seed,
and by the aspiration of my mind,
for a hundred thousand eons

analyzed: vinipātam na gacchati  āraddha vīriyaḥ pahitatto
translated: I will not go to the lower realms.’🔽Endowed with energy, intent,
and with the qualities of the mind,
at the age of seven years
I attained Liberation.
For sixty-four thousand eons,
I was called Bījamānasa,
and I was a powerful King,
a Universal Monarch.
I attained the four analytical knowledges,
and the eight liberations,
and I realized the six kinds of direct knowledge.
I have done what had to be done with regard to the Buddha’s instruction.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā vidhūpanadāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā vidhūpanadāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus has the venerable Vidhūpanadāyaka told these verses.
The Story of the Elder Vidhūpanadāyaka is finished.
